newsitem.title: FRANCE: Algeria to put unruly domestic market in order.
newsitem.headline: Algeria to put unruly domestic market in order.

text.p: Algeria's trade ministry announced on Tuesday measures to bring order to supplies of essential foodstuffs to local markets which have suffered shortages.

"The supply of the national market in basic foodstuffs has in the past few months experienced disruption and shortage, sometimes very deterimental to market stability and purchasing power of households," said the ministry, quoted by the official news agency APS.

The ministry gave few details of the new measures but blamed what it called "disfunctions" in the import system during Algeria's transition from a tightly state-controlled system to free market rules.
Algeria relies largely on imports for basic essentials like flour, sugar, coffee and semolina, the base ingredient for the local staple, couscous.
It said it would draw up a list of importers with expertise who would receive advice and help from the ministry, while it would keep an eye on the activities of other private importers.

Algeria moved from a three-decade old system of centralised state control towards a free market in 1990 -- two years after poverty riots erupted in which, according to independent estimates, 500 people were killed. The official death toll was 40.
